The course is very well organized and structured, which helped provide clear takeaways from the course. Broadly, behavioral finance can be divided into a set of empirical facts that traditional finance models have struggled to explain, and a set of "behavioral" theories that have been proposed. The course is well-structured to clearly outline puzzling and important empirical facts in finance as well as behavioral theories that can be used to explain these  empirical facts.

Strengths:
It opened a whole new world to me, a student who had only studied finance in the rational framework. 

Weaknesses:
The pace of the course is not uniformly distributed over the semester. It is a little bit tight in the first half, but too loose in the second half.

Improvements:
It may be a good idea to ask students to write a summary for some of the papers in the reading list. For example, they can choose 10 during the whole semester. It does not have to be long, a page maybe. It might be too much of workload, but it definitely helps students read and learn more.

The best economics class, maybe the best Yale class, I've taken, full stop. If you're looking for a primer on behavioral finance or even economics, take this class. Barberis teaches very well, providing an engaging and structured overview of the subject, backed with plenty of paper citations that gives the course a comforting amount of rigor, as opposed to the other "Behavioral Economics" SOM class that at times sounds like pop psychology. Barberis also draws out the math and models underlying the content, but emphasizes the broader qualitative conclusions in a way that makes the class very accessible for non-hardcore finance types like myself. I found this class very refreshing in the face of all the other economics courses centered around rational markets, because let's face it, people aren't totally rational, and those classical models only go so far. As a bonus, Barberis's British accent and cadence makes lecture pleasant to listen to.
